title: Summer Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview, oral board, written exam which were all very independent and in depth. Tough competition between 30 different applicants. Very fair interview process which did not take to long of time.
Interview Questions: What brought you hear today

title: Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: The hiring manager sent an interview request to me. Then, I was interviewed by him and one Research Scientist in the team. It is a pannel interview with 10 questions, they took turn to ask you questions. After that, they will do references check and make decision.
Interview Questions: 1. Why are you interested in this role? 2. Tell me a project you participated in using mixed methods, what is your responsibilities? 3. How do you do literature review? What is the process? 4. Tell me how do you use R or python in your project? 5. How do you collaborate with and approach to your faculties? 6. How do you help your faculty in a project? 7. What are your expectations for your supervisor? 8. Tell me a mistake you ever made? 9. Tell me the most challenging project for you? Why do you think it is challenging? 10. After three months in, how do we know if you are a good fit for this position or how do you see this position is a good fit for you?

title: Construction Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: Lengthy. Luckily I was gainfully employed. It took 7 interviews and took 3 months from initial application to offer. I have heard that applicants were unable to wait for an offer letter.
Interview Questions: Standard questions about past work. Asked about identifying successes, and failures. Overall, it was very conversational, and less focused on metrics.

title: Peer Advisor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: The process was relatively straight-forward with one round of interview questions asking about how we manage conflicts and questions related to the requirements on the job posting and a very understanding employer.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with conflict?

title: Business Systems Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: 4 rounds of interview, talked with great and friendly people, you first get a screening list of questions from HR and then interview request. The process does take a long time. I started interviewing October 2022 and received an offer letter January 2023
Interview Questions: How would you handle a difficult stakeholder

title: Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2+ months. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: The interview process itself feels clear, transparent, sets reasonable expectations. But there's a disconnect between how the interview goes and not being hired. Was told by two hiring managers that I aced my interviews, yet they went with another candidate.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when you worked with a community partner and there was conflict. How did you resolve it?

title: Software Engineer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Washington in May 2023
Interview Descriptions: With my several years of experience of working as an engineer, this was the worst and most unprofessional interview experience I've ever had in my life. Easy interview because the interviewers have low standards for hiring. If you work here, it'll probably be amazing because from what I've gained from the interview process, there seems to be a lot of thumb twiddling all day. Interviewers really liked to point out how slow moving UW is and the work life balance is amazing, insinuating that there's more life than work. A lot of the interviewers here seems to be taking refuge from the high stress environment of working in the tech industry, so I'd imagine this place is great for doing little to nothing and getting paid. After the two interview rounds, I hope you have enough time and money to live off of if you're unemployed because you will wait from at least a month and a half to, in some cases I've heard, up to a year before you hear an update. I was treated with unprofessionalism but respectfully followed up every week for over a month. Today, I received an offer from another company and let them know because they told me to notify them of any timing constraints and was rejected right away despite last week receiving an update that I am still being considered. I am not sure what they could have been doing for over a month instead of hiring someone and putting them to work. The last response I received gave off the idea that they were never really planning on hiring anyone. The position preaches that they're looking for industry talents to bring into academia where there is usually a lack of technological industry standards. Yet it's ironic that they hire in ways that are the complete opposite of industry standards. I wanted to work here because I thought the mission contributes to changing our understanding of the universe but unfortunately it's gate-kept by bureaucracy that doesn't make sense. My advice to the department is to not forget that the people you're interviewing have lives and bills they need to pay. If you leave people hanging for too long, they'll move on to better jobs and you will never hire anyone and just waste money and time instead of using what little funds UW has (after the administration sucks out most of it out of the wallets of students) to improve the lives of students on campus. It's just hiring someone for a job. How hard can it be that you need to take months to a year to process it? Universities are privileged with some important work for public organizations working in the discovery of the universe and the most meaningful work this world has to offer that could improve the lives of billions. Hoping the money that comes from tuitions and the government will be put to better use for that cause, starting with hiring the best talents in the best ways or at least let students graduate with less debt while NOT forcing them to live in dorms like tetris pieces.
Interview Questions: I forgot it was so long ago but the question was really open ended and they didn't really require you to code. Just talk about it and write some code on a google doc.

title: Doctoral Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: After completing the application, you are contacted about setting up an interview. It is a panel interview over Zoom, with a few faculty members that are potential mentors. Application deadline is in January, interviews take place around February or March.
Interview Questions: Interview Questions Tell us a little about yourself and why you applied to the special education doctoral program at the University of Washington. What are your career goals after obtaining your PhD? Our Special Education program specifically focuses on issues of access, inclusion, and equity for children and youth with disabilities and their families. How do your goals align with these commitments? Tell us about a time when you took professional feedback and made a change in your own practice. What are you excited about starting a PhD program? What else would you like us to know about you?

title: Help Desk Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions: I had to do submit a resume and cover letter. Then I had one interview with the supervisor that was nothing crazy, he sent the questions beforehand so I had time to think and recite my answers and was offered a job afterwards. It took about 1 week.
Interview Questions: what would you do if you got an angry patron? How would you handle the situation

title: Research Technologist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: In general, University of Washington takes a lot time to get back to you on applications. They say 4-6 weeks after the application deadline, but really it's going to be 6 weeks or longer until you hear back. Once you do hear back, you will most likely have a two phase interview: phone interview and then an in-person interview.
Interview Questions: I had some questions that were the usual questions you get in an interview, such as availability, what would I do in certain situations, etc. And I had some questions that were specific to the job I was applying for.

title: Academic Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Standard phone screen and then on-campus interview with a variety of stakeholders (potential team, leadership in the department, student panel). Only tedious part is that it took several months between each stage (apply, phone screen, interview).
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: one interview with the manager, and basic behavioral questions. one tutorial meeting explains the basic work we do. Really fast process and receive an offer one week after the interview
Interview Questions: Q: Introduce yourself and why apply for the role

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: They expected far more of the candidate than was required in the job description and I felt the interview process was ridiculous for the level of the job they were hiring.
Interview Questions: Where I store my code

title: Business Development Manager - Account Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington

Interview Questions: My friend and her boyfriend were just there and I y

title: Medical Technologist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Mar 2023
Interview Descriptions: UWHealth has one of the best online application platforms. After I submitted for the med tech position, I received a follow-up email from a recruiter to enter job preferences on datasets to express my interest. My applications are distributed to the labs that maybe fit my skillsets and available opportunities. After I reached out to the recruiter, I contacted from lead lab tech and had a phone interview with three managers.
Interview Questions: Tell me when you had a conflict with your coworkers and how you resolved it.

title: Internship Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Good interview with a helpful group that took me through a phone process and then a virtual discussion. Learned a lot about the company, its culture, and the working environment. I felt well treated.
Interview Questions: What is one skill you could contribute?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Through online website to process, do the interview, ask several questions let you answers. Like for yourself, quantitative questions and future plan questions. For example, why you choose this program?
Interview Questions: what is your future plan

title: Clinical Psychologist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: It is a group interview, where you will meet 2-3 psychologists. The process lasts an hour or so. Make sure you are familiar with the risk assessment. A question on diversity is asked.
Interview Questions: How would you assess suicidal risks?

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: 2 rounds of virtual interviews in total. 1st round is pretty basic, you talk about your background and your interest to the role. 2nd interview was with several staff and they asked around 10 questions regarding the required skills and responsibilities
Interview Questions: All of us encounter conflict from time to time in our work environment. Give us an example of when you have and how you handled it.

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Give them a self-introduction video and explain your strength. Your goal of the future. Your interest. Total time around 2 to 3 minutes. I formly dressed for this video recording.
Interview Questions: introduce yourself and your strength

title: Undergraduate Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Very easy process with one informal interview and a recommendation, got an offer letter in the email within 3 weeks. Was a very good experience, and I'm extremely thankful for the opportunity.
Interview Questions: Questions were related to previous experience.

title: Alumni Association Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: They take themselves very seriously. Multiple interviews, not a conversational process as in other private companies, not much effort to put the interviewer at ease in the beginning, just a rapid fire panel format for each interview. Their chosen process doesn't maximize the possibility of getting the best out of a potential candidate. Felt cold, not warm.
Interview Questions: Their process is very specific. Each interview is conducted with the exact same questions for each candidate so they can score candidates against each other. Yuck.

title: Data Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: The most critical application process at the UW is to be SURE that your resume (which is auto-parsed for keywords) ... and auto-weighted for duration attached to keywords ... racks up enough points that you even get to an interview ... It is wise to look at the requirements not just for your particial position but at the "level" requirements in general ... like Systems Analyst III vs Systems ANalyst 1 ... for salary range and expertise ... Being a public institution ... much like civil service they have to hire the most qualified ... but that is now weighted in point systems rather trhan actual skill levels ... and the inverviewer has a "score sheet" that they have to fill our to justify hiring mandy over jake ...for instance ... so you need to make it easy for them to add up the points to give you the job vs someone else ...
Interview Questions: What tools would you use to insure you have good cognitive horizon and awareness over multiple projects data that are in disparate databases ?

title: Peer Advisor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Easy, not too difficult if you're in major. Will likely draw on things from current and past experience in a similar roll. Be yourself and should be fine. Don't stress about the job too much.
Interview Questions: What do you look forward to most in position.

title: Clinic Representative Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: The interview was conducted over zoom and took less than 30 minutes. It was more of a conversation, very relaxed and informal. Not a big deal. Communication happened over email after that.
Interview Questions: What experience do you have?

title: Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington in Dec 2022
Interview Descriptions: Simple 30 minute interview process but took forever to hear back about next steps. The UW hiring process is known for being extremely long and bureaucratic. I wish they were better about communication and updates.
Interview Questions: 1. Tell me about yourself 2. Why are you interested in this position?

title: Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Washington in Dec 2022
Interview Descriptions: After applicaiton, first round was with HR recruiters for Advancement overall. They asked about salary expectations and a few experience based questions to verify your eligibility for the role. Next round was hiring manager (there were 5-10 finalists at this round) I didn't make it to the final round, but it consisted of meetings with the committee, team dean and on site tour.
Interview Questions: How have you committed yourself to diverse/ equitable advancement in higher ed? Examples of key competencies.

title: Facilitator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Take about a week, video call interview by Zoom platform with two professors. Get the result very quickly. There is one round of the interview. Take about a week, video call interview by Zoom platform with two professors. Get the result very quickly. There is one round of the interview.
Interview Questions: What is your favorite courses?

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Straightforward, you are given the questions beforehand to allow you time to think about your answers more deeply. "What are your strength and weaknesses?" "What a project you were most proud of and why?"
Interview Questions: "What are your strength and weaknesses?" "What a project you were most proud of and why?"

title: Coding Education Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington (Auburn, WA)
Interview Descriptions: After applying I was invited to a zoom group interview.  I was offered the position and unfortunately had to decline due to low offer. This was surprising considering the location, previously having the same position elsewhere years ago paying a considerable amount more, and inflation/economy. If the pay had been posted it would have saved everyone time.
Interview Questions: The interview consisted of basic interview questions. Nothing out of the ordinary or unexpected.

title: Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: They gave me the questions 15 minutes beforehand, which made it easier to be prepared. Pretty stock questions, but knowing what was coming took a lot of anxiety out of the interview.
Interview Questions: DEI, old roles, relationship management

title: Program Operations Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Sept 2022
Interview Descriptions:
Very straightforward interview process. Only had one initial call and then a panel interview. Probably the best interview experience I’ve had to date with the openness that the hiring manager and team displayed throughout the process. 

If your application is selected I would say you’re probably in good hands with the promptness and respect they show candidates.
Interview Questions: What current business practices/skills at my current job will make me the best candidate for the job I’m interviewing for?

title: Learning Designer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Sept 2022
Interview Descriptions: First there was a 20 minute phone call, then they invited me for a Zoom interview that lasted one hour.  There were 6 people on the interview panel, including another LD, a data person, the director (reporting manager), and others. They were really nice, and patient with me even though I had technical difficulties.
Interview Questions:
(Still awaiting their response--just want to fill out this review to be able to access glassdoor.com). 

They asked me to walk them through a work sample, then asked how I design assessments and engaging learning activities. They asked for an example of how I've dealt with a tight deadline line or challenging personality at work in the past. They also asked how I would deal with it if a SME designed their own course and just handed it to me to put online.

title: Instructional Design Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Sept 2022
Interview Descriptions:
The position I applied for seemed well-suited to my skills (relating to accessibility and curriculum development). Joining the interview, it became clear they were interviewing me for a different kind of position. Although the researcher who I spoke to was knowledgeable and easy to get along with, it was challenging to get a clear picture of the department's function and goals.

Ultimately, the qualifications expected were for someone mid to senior-level with a background in public policy (whereas the job description: high school diploma with clerical experience). Nonetheless, I was told I would hear back with a decision. I did eventually receive a message thanking me for my time and that I'd be a better fit for another one of their positions.
Interview Questions: What is your philosophy of education?

title: PhD Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Interviewed with the department faculty and met current graduate students in the program. The interviews were approximately 30 minutes in length and spanned a range of technical questions to questions about the interested in the program. In addition to the interview, we toured the campus and associated facilities.
Interview Questions: Why did you select the University of Washington graduate program?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions:
3 interviews
Very oganaized clear and concise 
Great place and even better environment. Would love to worm at tho remarkable place that can be rewarding and challenging for a perspective indicual that has the mental capability and diverse work background to succeed in such a place
Interview Questions: How can I contribute to their organization

title: Director of Digital Operations Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Aug 2022
Interview Descriptions: Recruiter set a meeting for the following day, which was great. They explained it was a screening interview taking 20 mins, max. When interview began, then they indicated it would take 75-90 mins to complete all the questions. I was surprised, but happy for the opportunity to share more about my experience.
Interview Questions: I was surprised with recruiter's very odd first question-- asked me to "guess their first interview question". I asked for clarification, and they said, "come on, you know what I'm going to ask, it's always the first question!" I replied "are you going to ask me to tell you about myself?" It wasn't-- they wanted to know my exact salary requirements.

title: Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Quick turnaround for administrative student assistant.  Standard questions about organizational capacity and administrative experience. Priority for upperclassmen, not told ahead of time and frustrating to deal with. Interview consisted mainly of discussing prior experience in similar roles.
Interview Questions: What is your level of proficiency with managing appointments.

title: Biomedical Equipment Technician I Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: The interview was about an hour and had a series of situational questions related to the work. Not much questions were asked for behavioral and wanting to know about the candidate more. The interview was fairly easy, but I have been applying to this position for more than 3 years and having an interview for their BMET 1 position was the furthest I reached.
Interview Questions: What is Patient Leakage Current?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: In a word, absurd. The stiff self-importance and total lack of authentic human interaction left me with no desire to work with them. For people like this, public health is a concept, a mechanism for generating funding and advancing careers, rather than the daily reality of so many communities of actual people.
Interview Questions: Every one was a lengthy, three-part question that was so long that by the time they got to the end, it was impossible to remember the whole thing. The final instance was with three minutes left in the interview time. I answered two-thirds of the question, but the third part was so absurdly broad and cumbersome that I asked the faculty member/PI if she could perhaps focus it a bit more so I could provide the most useful response, given the time. She stared back at me impassively and said, "Do you want me to repeat the question?"

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Interactive, friendly, very interested in my past work experience, and research experience, and whether that would be a great fit and contribute to a successful experience.  Would highly recommend.  Suggest researching the project you will be working on.
Interview Questions: Anticipated project that would be worked on.

title: Research Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions:
Innovative and enlightening. Interviewer was engaging and qualified which was refreshing and kept me interested and wanting to know more. 
It was a positive experience from a well seasoned interviewer
Interview Questions: What is your 5 year plan

title: Editor Interview
Application Type: The process took 6 months. I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Initial interview w 2 director-level physicians followed by site visit w an additional 4 interviews w lead administrator, PhDs and MD. These interviewers asked their own questions and in turn answered questions I had about the position. Each of these interviewers approved of my hiring.
Interview Questions: How will you create editorial content?

Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: ask me about techique I used before The University of Washington ranks No. 25 in the world, or fifth among U.S. public institutions for student experience, faculty prestige and quality of resea
Interview Questions:
where am i from?

title: Conference Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Interview was pretty basic and easy. Nothing super in dept. Just want to make sure you are competent and friendly for the most part. Emphasis on customer service and admin skills.
Interview Questions: Tell us about your past work experience.

title: Admissions Officer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Short 15 minute interview. You had to answer some mock emails. Other than that you just answer a few very short personality questions and you hear back relatively soon about whether or not you got the position.
Interview Questions: What do you do if a student is upset about their admissions decision?

title: Program Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Apr 2022
Interview Descriptions: Interview was virtual through zoom. Questions were behavioral type questions. There were about 6 questions asked and it took about 40minutes for the enitre interview process. 3 people interviewed me.
Interview Questions: Tell us about a time you managed multiple projects, what was the process and outcome

title: Compliance Services Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington in Apr 2022
Interview Descriptions: Had a phone screening with an HR Rep at UW, and made the first round of interviews within a week from first contact.  I was told I would hear back from someone regarding whether or not I was moving forward in the process, but I did not hear one way or another.  Interviewers were not prepared to give me enough time for questions. I would suggest that they leave enough time in the interview process for the interviewee to ask questions as well, this is a selective process for us as well.
Interview Questions: Why did you apply for this position?

title: Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Apr 2022
Interview Descriptions: I applied the position online and sent my resume and cover letter. After around 3 weeks, I received an email invitation to schedule a Zoom interview. The interview consisted of more than 10 behavioral questions and took about 45 minutes.
Interview Questions: Have you ever worked on something where it was crucial to be accurate? How did you go about it?

title: HR Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions:
Applied online, got an email to schedule a phone screen about 2 weeks later.  General conversation about the posting and the salary range. Second round was via ZOOM with 3 people - general scenario/behavior questions. Third and final was via ZOOM with the top 3 personnel in the office/college that I would be interacting with. By the end of the week my references updated me they were contacted then I got the offer.

Definitely do your research and look over the posting, take notes and ask good questions at the end of each. Think about the duties of the job as well as what is important to you in a work environment.
Interview Questions:
How do you prioritize your tasks and keep track of them?

Three strengths an three weaknesses?

How do you perform in fast paced workplaces?

General question about confidentiality and who gets to know what. Think FERPA.

title: Organizational Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at University of Washington in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: Responses to essay questions via email in lieu of a phone screen by a recruiter, then a 1:1 interview with the hiring manager followed by two panel interview rounds (one with 3 people and another with 6! people) with the hiring manager and team members (all via Zoom). It took three months, though 1.5 months of that time was due to the hiring manager being out for surgery. I declined an offer without even hearing the details because of too many red flags for me. One was that I had to present two different examples of training content and they gave feedback about it to me in the moment, which was odd. Usually for sample training facilitation examples the candidate doesn't receive immediate feedback, so this felt strange and was jarring. Plus, while the feedback was all positive from the team members on the panels, the feedback from the hiring manager was that it missed the mark because it didn't include information/address something he had in his head that it would...for sample content of 5 and 10 minutes in length. This signaled to me that he'd be difficult to work with - having some unrealistic and hidden expectation in his head that you were supposed to magically know about to fulfill. Mixed signals too, considering I received an offer and thought I blew it in both panel interview rounds. Also, there were A LOT of questions about handling conflict and difficult situations, including the oddest interview question I've ever heard (listed below). Very strange experience with some of the panelists coming across as stiff and impersonal. A hard "no" for me.
Interview Questions: "What was a time when you caused someone at work or a team difficulty and what did you do/how did you handle it?" Um, what? You mean, intentionally? Weirdest question ever. I think they were trying to get at conflict management in a bizarre way.

title: Food Court Employee Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: The process was easy. I was asked about my background and what kind of role I would like to take in the food court. They also told me that I will switch among restaurants from time to time. I was also inquired my availabilities during the week.
Interview Questions: Are you open to all kind of roles in the food court?

title: Instructional Designer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Not bad - - very polite, but bureaucratic. I guess that's what one would expect but I was surprised by the lack of flexibility in hiring options. The benefits are good.
Interview Questions: What are your future goals within UW system.

title: Associate Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: First there was a casual phone interview conducted via the popular telecommunication service Zoom. This phone interview was then followed by an in-person interview wherein I met the team and the interviewer.
Interview Questions: What interested you in this position?

title: Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions: The interview initially consisted of 30 min - 60 min Phone Screen with HR Admin Assistant and then a final Interview with investigators on Zoom (5 people maximum, 1 hour on Zoom)
Interview Questions:
What are three strengths and weaknesses?
Describe your biggest professional achievement

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions:
-Submitted my application & heard back from them with in two weeks.
- Behavior questions such as why are you applying, why got you interested in this role were asked
- Specific questions on the teaching topics. 
- Classroom simulation in which one of the interviewer was a struggling student.
Interview Questions: What got you interested in this job?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: Set up a Zoom call with prospective advisor for PhD. Easy and quick. The call lasted about an hour and was relaxed in pace, more so a conversation than an interview.
Interview Questions:
Self learner? Give examples.
What are your weaknesses?

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Washington
Interview Descriptions: The interview was through Zoom and I presented a scientific seminar and was asked about my prior experience, skillsets, previous education, etc. It was a fairly casual process and then there was a 1:1 interview with the PI
Interview Questions: Tell me about a conflict at work and how you resolved it.

title: Career Coach Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Washington (Seattle, WA)
Interview Descriptions:
Make sure you address ALL the questions they're looking for in the application. I made it to the first of what I assume would be two interviews for this position. I feel like I didn't get the position because I did not have DIRECT college career coach experience, despite the fact I had a decade of teaching experience at UW and several years career coaching of mid-career professionals.
The interview was a 30 minute panel interview conducted via Zoom. Four people total, but I had been told five. They were very specific that your camera was turned off and that you did not use a profile picture. They take DEI very seriously and did not want any opportunity to let unconscious bias creep into the process.
Interview Questions:
Questions included: 
-Tell us about yourself
-Why are you interested in the position?
-What gives you energy? (Think introvert/extrovert)
-You're advising a student who has applied to ten internships at Boeing and is preparing two more applications because they haven't heard anything. What do you tell them?
-When have you experienced equity in the classroom and how have you applied it?

There were other questions, but I don't have notes on them. Prepare like any other interview with a focus on DEI and you'll do fine.

title: Academic Adviser Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Washington in Nov 2021
Interview Descriptions:
The hiring process is long and delayed. Got my first interview about a month after applying to the position through UW Hires portal.  The first interview was a Zoom interview (camera on) one on one with the hiring manager. The administrative person who coordinated the interview stated it's a "phone call" in her email, and when I asked for clarification I got no response, which threw me off a little bit when I found out it's actually a camera on interview. Prior to the interview, you need to provide a response to their "short response questions", which essentially is like writing 3 mini-essays. It's stressful. 

The second-round/final-round interview was a panel interview. 2 hours long, needed to do a 10-minute presentation, and there were about 10 people joint the presentation.

The final result came out three weeks after the final round of interviews. I was told by the hiring manager that the process is very delayed because the HR department is understaffed. 

Notes: They check references for top candidates, so just because your reference is checked doesn't mean you're going to be hired. Be aware of this and provide your reference carefully, especially if you don't want your manager at the current job to know.
Interview Questions: How do you handle conflicts; examples about team projects; some situational questions/technical questions, such as what type of advice you would give to your students under XYZ situations.

title: Advancement Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Washington in Jul 2020
Interview Descriptions:
The process consisted of a phone interview, submission of diversity statement, an interview with executive leadership/supervisor, and then a panel interview with the team. I made it to the end of the process and my references were contacted. 

The process is incredibly long (4 weeks) and the communication on their end is rather nonexistent. I was informed that my references would be called and I would receive next steps. What was rather unfortunate, and completely inappropriate, is that the supervisor during the reference check had told me they respected my time and would be in contact with a decision promptly. They never followed up with me. Two weeks later I sent an email asking if they would let me know if they had decided to move forward with another candidate, but that message was ignored.

What is incredibly disheartening is that this position and the department under the Office of the Vice Provosts for Academic Student Affairs communicated that they focused on equity, diversity, and inclusion, but their hiring practices don’t reflect that. An arduous and time consuming hiring process is not equitable; a process can be competitive while still being equitable and inclusive. People not in executive leaderships roles do not possess the resources (be it time, money, other) to commit to processes such as these and then be left in the dark. People will remember these experiences – I will remember this experience. The executive leadership’s actions reflect highly on the mission goal and work done by the department and other Advancement teams at UW and, to me, it’s apparent that they are still focusing on equity and inclusion in theory and not in practice.
Interview Questions: How would you keep yourself organized while juggling different requests from different university departments?
